title: Robe à l'anglaise
creator: Batchelor, Ham and Perigal (textile designer)
notes: Silk: c. 1772-1773; Dress: c. 1783. This is an example of a dress that may have existed in another form earlier in the century, as indicated by the silk's dating. It has been included as it may have been alerted and that resulted in its later dating of 1783, but noentheless, the dress has value to this visual study, if even just for its earlier silk.

title: N/A
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)

notes: N/A

title: N/A
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)
provience: The shoes came with a gown and petticoat said to have been worn by Sarah Greene Hill (1700-1760) of Wickford, Rhode Island, for her wedding. Subsequent genealogical research, however, shows that Sarah Greene Hill (Mrs. Caleb Hill) was born in 1760, married in 1784, and died in the 1830s, making it unlikely that she ever wore the shoes that date 1750 to 1765. It is more likely that the shoes were passed down in the family and originally worn by Sarah Greene Hill's mother, Mary Waterman (Mrs. Thomas) Greene (1726-1765) or by Sarah's grandmother, Sarah Wicks (Mrs. Benoni) Waterman (about 1700-1786).
notes: These shoes have a corresponding dress (CW_1951-150,1).

title: N/A
creator: Anna Maria Garthwaite (textile designer)
provience: Family tradition stated that Sarah Greene Hill of Wickford, Rhode Island, wore this gown of imported English silk at her wedding. Family tradition further stated that she lived from 1700 to 1760. Judging from genealogical research, however, those dates are incorrect. It is more likely that the gown was first worn by Sarah Greene Hill's grandmother, Sarah Wicks Waterman, who was born in 1700 and married in 1724. The dress was later remade in the style of the late 1770s or early 1780s. The garment was probably remade for granddaughter Sarah Greene (1760-1839) when she married Caleb Hill on January 4, 1784.
notes: This dress has a pair of corresponding shoes (CW_1951-150,3A_v1). 1726-1728 (textile); 1775-1785 (gown)

title: N/A
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)
provience: The shoes descended in donor's family and were worn by a member of the Willis or Osgood family of Massachusetts. The most likely original owner was Mary Ball Willis in the 1770s.
notes: N/A

title: N/A
creator: N/A
provience: The original owner of the ensemble is listed as Mary Lynch, but the geneological information aligns with a woman names Maria Lents (it is likely simply a misreading or misspelling). She was baptised approximately 1709 and is said to have descended from the 1730-1731 acting governor of the New York colony, Rip Van Dam. Although this is unsubstantiated, she was certainly married to an Egbert Benjamin Egberts. They married in 1740, lived in Albany, owned property in New York City, and had four children. Her death date is unknown but at the time of Egberts' will in 1760 she was still living. A mourning locket in the New York Historical Society attributed to the Egberts family lists Egbert Egberts' death date as 1771 and Maria Lents' as 1784.
notes: These shoes match a woman's gown and two pocketbooks of the same imported Chinese silk damask (see Accession Numbers 1985-143, 1993-127, and 1993-128.) The gown, shoes, and pocketbooks were apparently worn in New York by the same woman in the 18th century and likely in the 20th century by a descendant of the family.

title: Sack, Saque, Robe à la Française
loc_origin: New York, America; New Jersey, America
creator: N/A
provience: This gown was handed down in the family from the original owner, Jane Sloan (Mrs. John Eatton) LeConte (1746-1826). Jane was born in New York and in 1776 married John Eatton LeConte, Sr. (1739-1822), from New Jersey. The couple appears to have lived most of their lives in Shrewsbury, New Jersey.
notes: Textile ca. 1740; gown 1770-1776.

notes: 1740-1760; remade ca. 1780. Temple holes in selvages indicating Chinese manufacture.

notes: Oral tradition holds that it may have been worn by a Philadelphia Quaker woman. The gown has been photographed with an eighteenth-century cotton kerchief and an English silk quilted petticoat.

title: Wedding shoes
loc_source: Historic Deefield and the Five Colleges
creator: N/A
notes: Pair of women's shoes in reddish-pink, glazed wool with buckles, which according to family tradition were worn for the January 24, 1765 wedding of Mary Flint (1742-1832) to Eleazer Spofford (1739-1828) in South Danvers, Massachusetts. Paper lables are attached to both shoes inscribed in ink: "Made for or brought from England for Mrs. Mary Flint-Spofford - wife of Dea. Eleazer Spofford of Bradford Mass., about 1760. Suppose to be the wdding shoes." It is likely that these shoes complemented the wedding dress, which could have been made of the same fabric.

title: Round gown
loc_source: Historic Deefield and the Five Colleges
creator: N/A
notes: Garments such as this good, but more ordinary gown are especially rare. According to family history, the dress is believed to have belonged to Anne Brooks (b.1744), the daughter of Joseph Brooks (1710-1750) and Mary Bliss (b.1710) who married in 1734 and moved to Palmer, Massachusetts. In 1765, Ann married Caleb Morgan of West Springfield, Massachusetts.

title: Wedding shoe
creator: N/A
notes: The toe is oval. It is upturned a little awkwardly, because the original heel of the shoe, which would have been of the Louis style, was replaced with a flat piece of leather (which is pegged along the front edge) sometime in the early nineteenth century to update the shoe's fashion. Little is known about Abigail Leverett. She married Stephen F. Johnson in 1776. Based on indepdent research into informaiton not provided by the CHS, this databse posists that Abigai Leverett was born in 1725 and lived in Neward, New Jersey when she owned this shoe.

title: Wedding shoe
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)
provience: Mary Simpkins Rand, Mary Rand Fitch
notes: According to the family history, these shoes were worn by Mary Rand (1776-1840) when she married Jeremiah Fitch in Boston on 10 May 1804. Jeremiah Fitch was the son of Jeremiah Fitch of Bedford. Because the shoes date too early for Mary Rand Fitch, it is likely that they were first worn by her mother, Mary Simpkins (b. 1744), daughter of William Simpkins, when she married Robert Rand, son of Robert Rand, of Boston, Massachusetts, on 3 June 1773.

title: N/A
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)
notes: N/A

title: Black satin shoe
creator: N/A
notes: Mary Trumbull was born in 1745, the daughter of Governor Jonathan Trumbull and Faith Robinson Trumbull. She was the sister of the Honorable Joseph Trumbull (b. 1737), Jonathan Trumbull, Jr. (1740-1809), Faith Trumbull Huntington (1742-1775), David Trumbull, and John Trumbull (1756-1843). Mary Trumbull married William Williams (1731-1811), a signer of the Declaration of Independence. She died in 1831.

title: Wedding shoe
creator: James Davis
notes: Hannah Whitman was born in Providence, Rhode Island in 1751. She was the daughter of Jacob Whitman. Hannah married Samuel Danielson on 16 May 1770. She died in Killingly, Connecticut, in 1781.

title: N/A
creator: John A. Wolfe
notes: No research into John A. Wolfe - cobbler in New York - seems to have been conducted as of Fall 2022.

title: Wedding shoe
creator: Hannah Edwards Wetmore (embroidery), Mary Edwards (embroidery)
notes: Two old labels attribute the embroidery of these shoes alternatively to Hannah Edwards and her older sister, Mary. Both attributions may be accurate. Two separate pairs of hands were almost certainly engaged in the embroidery. Perhaps each sister worked one shoe, in order to have them ready in time for Hannah’s 1746 wedding.

title: N/A
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)
notes: High-style women's dress shoes, of white silk brocaded with pink and brown flowers, originally belonging to Mary Ledyard (1735-1807) of Groton and Hartford, Connecticut. She was the daughter of Captain John (1700-1771) and Deborah Youngs Ledyard (1705-1746/7).

title: N/A
creator: N/A
provience: According to family history, Captain Lemuel White purchased the silk in China, had it made into a stomacher in either England or the United States, and then gave the stomacher to his wife, Mary Wells White, in 1794. However, the stomacher is much earlier than the family history states, because women were no longer wearing stomachers on their gowns by the 1790s. (Bassett 3/28/2001)
notes: The shape and style of the stomacher suggests that it was embroidered and constructed in Connecticut or possibly in England, around the second quarter of the eighteenth century. The design and workmanship of the embroidery indicates that it was done by an amateur, but it is charming in its design and use of color.

title: N/A
creator: N/A
notes: According to family history (Raymond & Aileen Sanford Family), this was made on an ancestor's family farm in Connecticut using linen made from flax grown on the farm, and wool from the family sheep dyed with vegetable dyes. The exact branch of the family that this petticoat comes from is still yet to be determined, although preliminary research is placing its origin somewhere in the northwest corner of Connecticut, around New Hartford, Simsbury, or possibly Granby.

title: Portrait of Jane Ellery (America, 1745-1787)
creator: John Durand (artist)
notes: Jane Ellery was born in December 1745, the daughter of John Ellery and Mary Austin Ellery, his second wife, of Hartford, Connecticut. She was the sister of Captain William Ellery and the granddaughter of Captain John Ellery and Jane Bonner Ellery. She was also the great aunt of Governor Thomas Hart Seymour. Jane Ellery never married. She died in Hartford, Connecticut, on 23 August 1787.

title: Formal open robe
creator: N/A
notes: According to museum records, Anne Beach Johnson (1729-1796) wore this dress to George Washington's first inauguration on 30 April 1789 at Federal Hall in New York. However, according to Lynne Bassett, CHS Costume Specialist, the style of this dress dates it ten to twenty years prior to Washington's inauguration; the dress would have been out of style by 1789, so it was likely not worn at that event. Anne Beach was born on 25 April 1729 the daughter of Sarah (died 1763) and William Beach. She married William Samuel Johnson (7 October 1727-14 November 1819) on 5 November 1749. He was the son of Reverend Dr. Samuel Johnson (1696-1772), the Anglican minister in Stratford, Connecticut and Charity Floyd Nicoll (died 1758)

title: N/A
creator: Mary Pierpont Russel, Mary Russell Talcott
provience: Mary Pierpont Russel, Mary Russell Talcott
notes: Mary Pierpont, daughter of Reverend James Pierpont and Mary Hooker of New Haven, Connecticut, was born 23 November 1703 in New Haven. On 19 August 1719, she married the Reverend William Russell (1690-1761), son of Reverend Noadiah Russell and Mary Hamlin Russell of Middletown, Connecticut.Mary Russell (b. 1720) was the daughter of the Reverend William Russell and Mary Pierpont (1703-1740). She was born in Middletown, Connecticut, in 1720. She married Matthew Talcott (b. 1713) on 29 August 1802; they had no children. Mary Russell Talcott's death date is unknown.

title: N/A
creator: N/A
provience: Hannah Avery Clark, Hannah Chaplin Avery
notes: According to the donor this shoe belonged to Hannah Avery Clark (1790-1886). However, since this shoe dates from 1765-1780, it is more likely that it was worn by her mother, Hannah Chaplin Avery (1759-1837). Hannah Chaplin married David Avery on October 10, 1782 in Mansfield, CT. 2763.1 is a dress with the same history, also more likely worn by Hannah Chaplin Avery.

title: Wedding shoe
creator: William Hose
provience: Lucy Lund Hutchins, Lucy Colburn Lund
notes: According to the donor this shoe was worn by Lucy Lund (1756-1833), the daughter of Lucy Colborn and Charity Lund, who married Col. Gordon Hutchins in 1780 (his second wife). However, the style of this pair of shoes indicates a date of the 1750s or 1760s, so it seems likely that Lucy's mother, Lucy Colburn Lund (1735-1805), wore them, possibly for her wedding to Charity Lund in about 1753 (her first child was born in 1754).

title: Wedding shoe
creator: John Hose (Johnathan Hose & Son)
notes: According to the donor this shoe was worn by Elizabeth Lord at her wedding to Jared Eliot, 1760. Town records of both Lyme and Killingworth, CT confirm this marriage on April 17, 1760; the Lyme record says Jared was from Killingworth, so it is likely the marriage took place in Lyme, where Elizabeth was baptized, the daughter of Richard and Elizabeth (Lynde) Lord in 1735, apparently the last of seven children including a previous Elizabeth who died in infancy. Her father was a wealthy landowner and civic leader in Lyme. Jared Eliot was descended from several prominent ministers and governors. His first wife had died in 1759; the marriage resulted in no children. Jared and Elizabeth Eliot had thirteen children, all but two of whom lived to adulthood. Jared died in 1812 and Elizabeth in 1820.

title: N/A
creator: N/A
notes: According to the donor this shoe was worn by Martha (listed in the Rhode Island Vital Extracts as both Mary and Polly, but not Martha) Brown (1740-1801) at President Washington’s Inaugural Ball in 1789. Martha Brown married David Howell (1747-1824) on September 30, 1770. They lived in Providence, Rhode Island, and David Howell was a delegate from Rhode Island to the Continental Congress. Martha/Mary would have been 49 years old in 1789.

title: N/A
creator: N/A
provience: Harriet Brewster Caldwell, Freelow Williams Brewster
notes: According to the donor these shoes were worn by Harriet Brewster Caldwell. Considering the date, however, they were probably worn by her mother, Freelove Williams, who married Samuel Brewster (1737-1824).

title: N/A
creator: N/A
notes: According to donor and inscription this shoe was worn by Amelia Hawkins, 1774 to a ball in Medford, Mass. which George Washington attended. It is known that Washington was in Medford during the early years of the revolutionary war, but whether there was a ball at that time is unclear. The style of the shoe (its heel shape and the silk design) suggests it may date closer to 1780. Research is under way to try to identify Amelia and clarify and confirm other parts of this shoe's story.

title: Robe a`l'Anglaise
creator: N/A
notes: The donor ascribed the dress to Christiana Beatty (1685-1776), believing it to have come over with her on her emigration from Ireland in the 1720s. Christiana emigrated with her brother Charles Clinton, the founder of the prominent New York family. However, the silk dates to the 1740s. It may have belonged to Christiana at a later date, or it may have belonged to a later generation.

title: Robe a`l'Anglaise???? and Matching Petticoat Panel
creator: N/A
provience: Family history relates that this dress was worn by Elizabeth Park of Concord, Massachusetts at her marriage to Nicholas Baylies in 1738. She would have continued to wear it for many years, and like most 18th century dresses, it has been completely taken apart and remade at least once.
notes: In 1738, the bodice would not have met at center front, but would have had pleated edges ("robings") forming a V in front, and a V-shaped panel called a stomacher would have been pinned or sewn into the center of the bodice. In the 1770s when the stomacher style was replaced by bodices which met at center front, this dress was reconfigured by removing the robing pleats and adding strips of silk at center front. Great care was taken to make the design of the silk match at center front. The lining extends without a seam all the way to center front and thus dates to this later construction. At some point, an extra panel of the silk was basted into the open front of the dress to create the illusion of a matching petticoat.

title: Robe a`l'Anglaise
creator: N/A
notes: Donor history stated that this dress was worn by Anna Barbara Muhlenberg, wife of General Muhlenberg. Anna Barbara Muhlenberg was married in Philadelphia on November 6, 1770. She was born in 1751. Her husband Peter was born in 1746, and lived at "Trappe Farm" in Providence, Pennsylvania in Montgomery County.
